case_vignette:
A 13-month-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of rectal bleeding that occurred earlier that morning. The patient has also had several itchy and red skin lesions that started on his scalp and spread downwards. The parents report that their son has had six episodes of bilateral otitis media since birth. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 3rd percentile for height and weight. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows several eczematous lesions over the scalp, neck, and upper and lower extremities, as well as multiple red spots that do not blanch on pressure. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 9.4 g/dL
Leukocyte count 11,500/mm3
Platelet count 30,000/mm3
Prothrombin time 14 sec
Partial thromboplastin time 33 sec
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?"

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I had rectal bleeding earlier this morning and I've been having several itchy, red rashes that started on my head and spread downwards.
How old are you?
I am 13 months old.
Are you currently experiencing any fever, joint pains, or abdominal pain?
I am not having any fever, joint pains, or abdominal pain.
Have you recently been given any new foods, medications, or vaccinations?
My immunizations are up-to-date, but there's no mention of new foods or medications recently given to me.
Do you have a history of allergies or similar symptoms in the past?
I've had six episodes of bilateral otitis media since I was born.
Has there been any change in your stool pattern or the presence of blood in the stool before today?
The only information provided is about the rectal bleeding that occurred earlier this morning; there's no mention of any previous changes in my stool pattern or blood in the stool.
Do you have a family history of bleeding disorders or gastrointestinal diseases?
The vignette doesn't give any information about my family history.
Given the limited information, have you had any recent illnesses or infections?
I've had six episodes of infections in my ears since birth.
**Final Diagnosis:** Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP).

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A 13-month-old child presents with rectal bleeding earlier in the morning and itchy, red rashes that started on the head and spread downwards. The child has not experienced fever, joint pains, or abdominal pain. Immunizations are up-to-date and there is no mention of new foods or medications. The child has had six episodes of bilateral otitis media since birth. There is no mention of any previous changes in stool pattern or blood in the stool. The vignette does not provide any information about the family history. The child has also had six episodes of infections in the ears since birth.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I came in because I experienced rectal bleeding this morning.
How old are you?
I'm just a little over a year old, 13 months to be exact.

No, I haven't had any recent episodes of diarrhea or constipation.

Final Diagnosis: Anal fissure or juvenile polyp. Further examination including physical inspection and possibly anoscopy or sigmoidoscopy is required to confirm the specific cause of rectal bleeding in this pediatric patient.

trial_1.summarized_conversation: A 13-month-old child is brought to the clinic due to rectal bleeding experienced in the morning. The child has not had any recent episodes of diarrhea or constipation and has not shown any signs of pain or discomfort with the bleeding. This is the first time this has happened, and the child is not on any medications. There have been no changes in the child's diet or introduction of new foods recently. There is no history of allergies or gastrointestinal diseases in the family, and the child does not have a fever, vomiting, or noticeable change in behavior.
trial_1.singleturn_frq: **Final Diagnosis:** Rectal bleeding without further context is nonspecific and can be due to various conditions. A diagnosis cannot be made without additional information.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I had bleeding from my bottom earlier this morning, and I've had itchy red skin spots that started on my head and have spread down my body.
How old are you?
I'm a 13-month-old boy.
Do you have a fever or any other symptoms?
No, my vital signs are normal.
Have you had any recent infections or illnesses?
I've had six ear infections on both sides since I was born.
Are you currently on any medications or have you recently finished any treatments?
No, I am not on any medications.
Do you have a family history of bleeding disorders or any other hereditary conditions?
I don't know about my family's medical history.
Have you had any recent vaccinations?
Yes, my immunizations are up-to-date.
Final Diagnosis: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

trial_2.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis is Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.
